content:
Dear David, I am not stupid or trying to be difficult. The problems I am having are due to a disastrous update of Thunderbird that was automatically uploaded to my Linux computer by Mozilla. The degree of difficulty with doing anything on this update is mind-boggling.

I have attached two photos that I took with my phone because the screenshot apps will not stay open while I open the part of the Thunderbird screen that I am having trouble with. The first photo is the beginning of the Tools dropdown. Unfortunately, my hand slipped and I did not get the "Tools" header. I did get the "Tools" header in the second shot. There is no "Account Settings" on this menu list. The only place I can find Account Settings is on the page you get when you have selected a mail account name, i.e., bdj@dj-group.org (as opposed to choosing Inbox where you get the email list).

Lord knows, *I* know how difficult this is, I've been living with it ever since it exploded on my computer.

My hope has been to remove all but three email accounts from Thunderbird so that with the limited scrolling this misbegotten update will allow me - I'll be able to reach my Local Folders - which I can't reach now. I've already added the lesser used email accounts to another Linux mail program. Why don't I switch completely to that new mail program. Because it doesn't have the features of Thunderbird, it doesn't take a calendar.ics file. It's a poor substitute for a well operating Thunderbird.

What this needs is for Mozilla to fix the update they sent me. Every morning when I open my computer, the first thing I see is a pop-up screen, "Thunderbird has crashed. Do you want to open it. Underneath the message is a box to provide comments. I provided comments for days and got nothing.

I'm sorry for all this. But David, I'm not stupid or crazy. The things you've pointed to - over the many messages we exchanged - simply aren't where you expect them to be. This is a totally messed up piece of software.

I don't know if there's any more you can do for me, unless you can reach someone at Mozilla to do something about this software update.

Thanks for everything. Barbara

content: If all you need is the addressbook, here is how to do that: - on old PC, start thunderbird, - click help>troubleshootinginformation (or help>moretroubleshootinginformation) - scroll down to 'profile folder' in left side bar - click open folder' - exit Thunderbird - You are now in the profile. there will be a file named abook.sqlite if a recent version of Thunderbird or a file named abook.mab if an older version. Copy to a USB stick - on new PC, - start TB, click tools>import>importfromafile, then 'import addressbooks', then select the addressbook type

content: Very important to have Thunderbird shut down prior to copying the profile. Otherwise, it will be corrupted and will act as you described. I suggest creating fresh backup of old PC with TB not running, copying the appdata\roaming\thunderbird folder as you indicated. And the copy to same place on new PC with TB NOT RUNNING there either.

content: If TB states that it cannot find profile, then the odds are that the profile is totally corrupt. To confirm this, use Profile Manager to set up the profile. You can press windows key and 'r' key and enter thunderbird.exe -p and then select 'create profile' and then click next and then enter a name (e.g., myprofile), and then click the browse button to locate and select the profile. That ensures that TB is looking at the desired profile. If the profile is corrupt, I am not the one to know how to make it right. If the accounts are IMAP, I would suggest starting over at some point, or by copying message files if POP and reconstructing. If you still have the profile as it worked in 115, that is another option. 115 does look different, but with a few setting changes, it is similar to 102.

content:
This can be done with css: 

/* threads pane lines*/ table[is="tree-view-table"] td {      border-bottom: solid 1px blue !important; }


Help/Troubleshooting Info, Profile Folder, Open Folder, close TB, create a new folder named chrome, create a new document in chrome with a text editor, name it userChrome.css, Save as type: All files *.*, copy in the above code, change the number as desired. Double-click toolkit.legacyUserProfileCustomizations.stylesheets to true in Settings/General/Config. editor, restart TB.

Online css generator

video on how to create a css file (Firefox and TB)

Add zebra striping: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1426382
creator: sfhowes

content:
For anyone who is still having trouble with this, this is the 3rd time that updates over the last 4 years have caused the lines between email headers to disappear for me, and each time it's been the .css file, which needed to either be generated or to be changed as the program evolves over time. I just made the changes according to the new code requirement and it's worked for me. I encourage you to just take this a step at a time. SFHowes has been the moderator who has helped me every time, and their directions do work. Here are some things to check, that I have adapted from an ancient support board for TB, that were helpful to me.

1. It is userChrome.css and not userchrome.css. The C in chrome MUST be capitalized.

2. Make sure you are in your actual profile folder. You can do this by using Help -> Troubleshooting Information (in Thunderbird). In the tab that opens, scroll down to Profile/Open Folder button and click it. You should get a Windows Explorer window that opens to your profile folder. Make sure that you put the userChrome.css file inside the chrome folder in your profile folder. [Follow the directions in SFHowes's post above about creating a new chrome folder and how to create the .css file correctly.]

3. To expand on the last setting in SFHowes's post, first I copy the post: <<<Double-click toolkit.legacyUserProfileCustomizations.stylesheets to true in Settings/General/Config. editor, restart TB.>>> In TB, go to Settings/General and scroll down all the way to the bottom where there is a button for Config.editor. Click button. Type "toolkit.legacy" in the search box, which makes the correct file appear (or choose the correct one if more than one appears)-- if it says false, click the buttons on the far right to toggle to true, if it already says true you don't need to do anything. NOW, close TB and the lines should be in place when you reopen.

4. Where SFHowes's code for the .css says "blue" you can put in a different color, such as red. I use grey, which softens the lines in a good way for me.

Hope this helps some.

--Victoria

content: There is only one font setting for Thunderbird, so it applies to all accounts. You could create different templates for each account, but that's not a complete solution. My suggestion is to create a separate profile for each and switch between the two. You could click help>troubleshootinginformation, scroll down to 'profiles', click 'about profiles' and then click the 'create profile' and create a new profile in which you would create the second account and could then set whatever fonts and colors desired and then delete that account from the other profile. Once done, you could use these same clicks to switch between the two.
creator: davidsk

content:
When a default setting is applied by the developers in a completely new set of code, the one used is chosen to suit a wide user base, but it's impossible to know what every user desires because people use different screen resolutions and different scales and different size screens and on top of that people have different eye sight requirements. So what works on one monitor/screen may not work on another. It's just not possible to get it perfect for everyone.

That's why Thunderbird 115* has improved the ability to set up everything to tune to each persons requirements. You do not need to access the Config Editor nor use a 'userChrome.css'.

Please read this info:

Via 'Menu Bar' toolbar:

  • View > Font Size > increase font size - repeat clicks on this to increase size in increments.

Via 'Menu app' icon on Unified toolbar:

  • Menu app icon > Font Size - click on the + icon to increase font size - repeat to increase size in increments.

The above will effect Folder Pane, Message List, Menus etc. It will also effect the 'Message Pane' to varying degrees because that area may also be controlled via :

  • Settings > General
  • Under 'Language & Appearance'
  • click on 'Advanced'
  • Select 'Fonts for : 'LATIN'
  • Set all the font sizes making sure the minimum size font is lower or same size'
  • Then select 'Fonts for: 'OTHER WRITING SYSTEMS'
  • repeat exactly the same for all font size settings so they match what you set up in 'LATIN'
  • Finally reselect 'LATIN'
  • Click on 'OK'

As an example - I like size 12px for Font size in Folder Pane etc, but in my incoming messages and emails I compose, I prefer to set a font size of 16 and a minimum size of 12.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: PS As a heads up, please do not use capital letters as it implies you are shouting at the very person who is offering their free time as a volunteer to help you. I'm letting you know about this because it's possible you are not aware of what capital letters mean in a forum. However, it's OK to use capital letters in certain circumstances, as an example if emphasizing something such as in my previous comment.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
I understand ALL CAPS as shouting. ALL CAPS are as annoying as the forced changes set as default. I used them as a demonstration of how a simple difference can make text hard to read.

I got the font size changed but have a few other needs to get back to the old look.

How do I get the Menu bar back to the top with the Toolbar "Addressbook, Write, Delete, Forward," under it?

How do I get rid of the circles around the number signifying emails in a folder. Those tiny white numbers in the colored circles are near impossible to read.
creator: MarkinIdaho

content:
re: How do I get the Menu bar back to the top with the Toolbar "Addressbook, Write, Delete, Forward," under it?

I was not impressed with the decision to put the main Menu Bar below the Unified Toolbar. I was equally unimpressed when I tried to get this option made available in Settings - like the Titlebar - and was given a resounding not going to happen. What really annoyed me is that I know it's not that difficult to move the position of something that already exists. So, I created my own question and answer for this because so many people were asking for it.

  • https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1422908

I know you did not want to use userChrome.css, but if you want a fix then there is no choice.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
re :How do I get rid of the circles around the number signifying emails in a folder. Those tiny white numbers in the colored circles are near impossible to read.


I asked about getting rid of those as well. Some were round, some were losenged shape and they are not aligned correctly. I find it very messy. So this has been reported as a bug. https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1836460

In reporting bugs you wil find the developers get really sensitive - they do not like it when people use plain simple language to explain the problem even if there is no offensive language etc.

such as this: Developer said: Little heads up, maybe it wasn't your intention but I would kindly ask you to use a less direct tone when writing messages. Writing things like

(In reponse to me saying)

  • NO this is wrong.
  • They are all over the place.
  • It's a mess.

Developer continued to say: comes off as confrontational and it's not a good way to grab the attention of core developers. It actually produces the opposite effect.

Which basically is a sort of threat saying if you say anything which we do not like then we will deliberately ignore it.

So as a heads up - if you want to report or comment in a bug - please remember the developers are a very sensitive bunch.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
The Folder Pane unread and total counts can be styled, hidden, or hidden for individual folders.

http://forums.mozillazine.org/viewtopic.php?f=39&t=3111573
